content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

I see four sections of tissue, which appear to be lymph nodes embedded in adipose tissue. All four lymph nodes show extensive replacement by a dense, basophilic (dark purple) cellular infiltrate, which is highly suspicious for metastatic carcinoma. The normal lymph node architecture seems to be largely effaced. My initial impression is that these are all positive lymph nodes.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I am zooming into the largest lymph node on the left, which appears to be almost completely replaced by tumor. The selected area is within the dense tumor deposit. The purpose of this zoom is to examine the cytological and architectural features of the infiltrating cells at high magnification to confirm that they are malignant and to characterize the type of tumor. Specifically, I am looking for features of adenocarcinoma, such as gland formation, nuclear pleomorphism, hyperchromasia, and necrosis, to confirm the diagnosis of metastatic colorectal cancer. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my task is to identify and count all positive lymph nodes for accurate cancer staging (N stage). While other nodes appear obviously positive, it is crucial to examine every potential lymph node, regardless of size. The area in the green box highlights a small, well-circumscribed lymphoid aggregate. I need to zoom in to determine if this is a lymph node and, if so, whether it contains metastatic carcinoma, as even a small focus of metastasis would classify it as a positive node. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area to confirm my initial suspicion of metastatic disease. This specific lymph node (the first on the top right) shows extensive replacement by abnormal-appearing tissue. I need to examine the cellular morphology at high magnification to confirm that these are malignant epithelial cells (carcinoma) and to assess the pattern of infiltration, which would definitively classify this node as positive for metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this specific area, located at the periphery of the first and largest lymph node on the left, to assess for extranodal extension (ENE). This location is the interface between the tumor-infiltrated lymph node and the surrounding adipose tissue. Examining this junction is critical to determine if the tumor has breached the lymph node capsule and invaded the perinodal fat, which is a key prognostic factor and a requirement for staging. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I would systematically examine each lymph node to screen for metastatic carcinoma. The green box is placed on the bottom right lymph node, which is the fourth node I would likely examine in a clockwise pattern. This area is densely cellular (dark purple), which could be either a benign reactive lymphoid follicle or a nest of tumor cells. High magnification is necessary to assess the cellular morphology and architecture to make this distinction. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see sheets of malignant cells forming irregular, crowded glands. The tumor cells have large, hyperchromatic, and pleomorphic nuclei with irregular nuclear contours. There is evidence of 'dirty necrosis' (glandular luminal debris), which is a characteristic feature of colorectal adenocarcinoma. The overall features are unequivocally those of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is confirmed: this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see a small, well-encapsulated lymph node surrounded by adipose tissue. The node is composed of a dense, monotonous population of small, round, dark-staining cells, which are characteristic of lymphocytes. I do not see any atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or cohesive nests that would indicate metastatic carcinoma. The subcapsular sinus at the bottom appears clear. Therefore, my impression is that this is a benign, reactive lymph node, negative for metastasis. The dark, linear structure across the top half is a sectioning artifact.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see densely packed, back-to-back malignant glands and solid nests of tumor cells, confirming metastatic adenocarcinoma. The tumor cells have large, hyperchromatic, and pleomorphic nuclei. There is a complete loss of the normal lymphoid tissue structure. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node, heavily involved by metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I can see the edge of the lymph node. On the right and bottom, there is dense lymphoid tissue, representing the tumor-infiltrated node. At the top and center, there is mature adipose tissue. The crucial finding is at the interface, where I can see irregular tongues and clusters of tumor cells infiltrating directly into the surrounding adipose tissue, accompanied by a desmoplastic stromal reaction (pink fibrous tissue). The lymph node capsule appears to be breached. My impression is that this confirms the presence of metastatic carcinoma with definite extranodal extension (ENE).
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I see multiple well-circumscribed nodules of densely packed small lymphocytes. These are lymphoid follicles. Some follicles show features of reactive germinal centers, with a mix of cell sizes and tingible body macrophages. The cells have the typical appearance of lymphocytes, not the large, pleomorphic, gland-forming cells expected of metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this field shows reactive follicular hyperplasia, a benign finding. I would continue to scan the rest of this lymph node to confirm the absence of tumor.
